comment: Much different than their single malts. For a young whiskey this doesn't really show it. You get a healthy dose of honeyed bourbon spice, while it develops that sweet sherry tang before leaving a crisp woody finish. Most certainly something to be sought after to replace your other everyday Irish sippers.
My first taste of this whiskey was a very pleasant experience. A touch hot on the front end, but a nice sweet and fruity taste as well. I’m definitely not done with this distillery’s products.

Sweet syrupy nose, hints of vanilla and honeysuckle also appear given some time. Flavour is pretty light with a bit more floral notes showing up. Has a bit of a cream soda or cola flavour as well. Finishes like liquorice. Good budget bottle!

quite simply didn't get it.  tried it at a tasting.  had none of the attractions of an irish whisky for me, with a short and abrupt profile and a thin feel.  grain with no notes.  sure - it was booze.  even "in-style" - i don't get it.
Stronger than their poitin, this is also a bit more complex

Introduced to this whiskey at Portstewart Golf Club, Northern Ireland, back in Sept. 2016.  Admittedly, the mystical experience of playing this majestic masterpiece, and host of the 2017 Irish Open, may have  prejudiced my sensibilities, but I found the spirit to be quite likable. This young distillery started as an aging and finishing agent of whiskies acquired elsewhere, but now has a new facility scheduled to open in 2017.  For me, this double barrel offering lacked the sweetness often associated with a blended Irish whiskey, and was more reminiscent of a dry Scottish highlander. The spirit imparts a fruitiness that complements well with elements of vanilla and almond. All in all, this portends a bright future for a concern founded by 5 friends with a dream. I may have rated it higher, save for the spirit's fuzzy heritage.

Actually Triple Barrel
Select Barrel Release for Tri-State
Batch 37
Bottle 129/156
Honey in color in the glass. Honey, spiced baked Apple, and finishes with a touch of sherry. Baking spices, honey, and warm apple pie. Has some heat on the finish. A hearty style of Irish whiskey.
Heavy burn with sweet nutty notes
Boozy apricot/sweet nose. Definitely get the sweet honey flavor right away. Then a nice vanilla/spice flavor with a hint of that bourbon barrel. Very easy drinking for sure!
3.5 almost 4 stars. Love the sherry finish. More to say when I taste again.
Even with the sharp alcohol taste it's still able to deliver the sweet & fruity flavours.
Rare fine but a little astringent, really nice smell. But it’s still something to remember. Takes water well but this short harsh finish.

I tried Glendalough Double Barrel on a tour in Irish Whiskey Musem in Dublin. On that weekend I tried plenty of Irish Whiskeys and this one I will recommend least. A lot of alcohol burining, very quick finish. It definitely could use more time in the barrell…

Similar to Southern Comfort both on nose and palette. Sherry taste is very distinct. Finish short and unremarkable. 

Such a unique whiskey. Definitely worth tasting.
Not my cup of tea.  A mixture of flavours that aren’t complimentary
Mild, fruchtig in der Nase, angenehm süß auf der Zunge und im Nachgeschmack

Nose: Lime/ citrus,ginger, vanilla, pear. Really pretty on the nose.
Taste: Follows up with the nose. The Sherry comes out more as you add water.

Nose: Ethanol, heavy banana cream (medicinal), vanilla, plums, stonefruit

Taste: Not as prominent banana, almond, plums, BlackBerry in the finish
Obvious sherry notes on the nose.  Friendly, sweet, slightly fruity palate.  Pleasant lingering finish and all at a reasonable price!
By far my favorite whiskey. Smooth all the way through with strong vanilla and nutty flavor with a fruit floral scent
Sweet caramel, vanilla, toffee, floral, spice, coffee. Can taste a ‘corn’ bourbon characteristic.
Whoa this is sweet on the nose, butterscotch candy and capri sun. The palate isn't too complex with raisins and caramel. Not much else, and no burn. This is very one note, not recommended.
Pleasant. A light whiskey with predominance of wood. The oloroso comes through much more than the american oak. I wouldn't buy it.

A different style of Irish for me. Still, I like this youthful spirit. The nose is very fruity, but shifts to caramel toffee and vanilla on the palate. It is peppery in the mouth too , but seems a bit rough or has some alcohol taste too. The finish is drying, and some more red fruit come back too. Overall very tasty but a bit off balance. (3.5 stars)
There is something different about this than , say, regular Tullimore D.E.W.--which I also like. I think it must be the slight "bourbonish" notes?  Anyway, it's worth drinking.

- apricot 
- plum
- jam
- orange zest
- toffee 
- coffee
- vanilla
Whiskey is sweet smooth but mono flavor

Neat. 
Very Interesting smell, sweet herbal? Fruit? Tastes Mild, sweet, then spicy tingle from the alcohol.

A splash of water.
Liked it less. Stick to neat.

Looking forward to trying more.
Alcohol and citrus nose. Smooth buttery taste. Medium short finish.
Just a couple rocks. Love this whiskey. Currently drinking the 2017 original release. Subtle smokiness and a smooth off sweet finish
A strong dose of alcohol on the finish I find a bit intense, but sweet mouth and kind of nutty. Enjoyable.
Excellent sweet grain blend, love at first sip.

Proof 66 does a nice job of summarizing how this whiskey is aged in both bourbon and sherry barrels. It noses of honey, cereal grains, lemon, and a little fig or raisin, or, perhaps cherry. On the tongue these all come across, but the sherry fruit flavors are not as obvious as the nosing predicted. The finish ends in a sweet spiciness. Distiller rates this an 86, and Whiskeyreviewer gives it a C+. I think I fall between those two. This is good; but, if I am looking for an Irish with a sherry note, I would prefer The Irishman and Powers Signature. I am sure there are others, but these I have in my collection. (Later this week my case of Redbreasts and a Green Spot will arrive. I will post my notes as soon as I am able.)
Smooth and refreshing!  I love it

Nose is fruity, almost fall. Apple cinnamon

Taste is clear water then immediately into sweet caramel, with floral or perfume. 

Has a cinnamon candy, honey brown sugar taste

DELICIOUS!!

Nose: very very sweet, raspberry, strawberry, cream, perfume, a hint of spice? 
Body: smooth, rounded, followed by cinnamon spice, medium-bodied
Palate: strawberry, overpowering cinnamon, hot tamale candy, some floral notes, slightly herbaceous 
Finish: not very long, but dry and cinnamon, bits of vanilla oak
Really nice and probably under rated Irish. Caramel flavours from the bourbon, plus some nut too.
Definitely on the sweeter and mild side of whiskey

Very different, first Irish that didn’t come off the bottom shelf.

Fruity on the noise kind of hot but not unbearable.  Citrusy with green notes, kinda like a mandarin orange with the leaves still on at Christmas, slightly floral like walking near a  patch of daises still in the ground.

Full and sweet on the palate very butterscotch with buckwheat honey and peppercorn.

Finish is spicy and tart, bitter almond extract.
remarkably smooth, very sweet port nose, lingering bourbon spice
Amazing Irish Whiskey. The sherry cask finish gives it a smooth finish.

I would like to rate this as a 4.1, but this site does not allow that.  this is a tasty Irish whiskey.  for an Irish, it has a creamy, soft mouth feel, it tastes as though it has a little single malt-though, I don't think it does, and is well rounded with a nice sherry accent.  If you can get this for around $30 I would say it is a good deal.
A bit hot on the nose, but really nice apple spice and stone fruit on the nose and mid palate, not too sweet, well balanced.

Very interesting Irish whiskey. At certain points it tastes like single pot still, other it tastes like a more grain-based spirit. The oak character is a bit overbearing for my liking but very pleasant with sherry and vanilla notes. I would like it if this whiskey only saw one barrel and stayed their longer.
